newsitem.title: USA: Venezuelans progressing in NY aluminium talks.
newsitem.headline: Venezuelans progressing in NY aluminium talks.

text.p: Venezuelan officials met representatives of the Japanese consortium that owns 20 percent of aluminium smelter Venalum in New York Wednesday and the talks are likely to continue tomorrow, the Venezuelan Consul General in New York said Wednesday.
"The negotiations are progressing today, we had a full day yesterday and are likely to meet tomorrow also," he told Reuters.
"But at this stage I cannot tell you commercial details of the talks, though we may have further information tomorrow," he said.

The Venezuelan government wants to privatize its interests in the aluminium industry, but the Japanese consortium that owns 20 percent of the smelter wants compensation for the special voting rights attached to its stake, and also wants the Venezuelan government to restart shipments under a 90,000 tonne per year contract which was suspended in February.
The Japanese consortium which owns the 20 pct stake in Venalum includes Showa Denko KK, Kobe Steel, Sumitomo Chemical Co Ltd, Mitsubishi Materials Corp, Mitsubishi Aluminium Co Ltd and Marubeni Corp.

The Venezuelan governments interests in the aluminium industry include a controlling stake in the smelters Venalum and Alcasa, along with carbon anode producer Carbonorca and bauxite and alumina producer Bauxilium.

On Wednesday last week the Venezuelan Investment Fund (FIV), which is organizing the privatization of the aluminium interests, said 13 companies had qualified to bid for the four company aluminium sector including Aluminium Co of America (Alcoa), Gencor Ltd, Glencore Ltd, Reynolds Metals Co, Norsk Hydro ASA, and RTZ Corp-CRA Ltd.
